policies.name: JWT Scope Validation
policies.exampleHtml:
Validates that the JWT token includes specific scopes

Options

policies.name: GraphQL Disable Introspection
policies.exampleHtml: Disables introspection queries on your API. This is useful in production to prevent attackers from learning about your API. You can still keep introspection enabled for any request not going through Zuplo.

policies.name: Quota
policies.exampleHtml: Enforce quota policies on requests.

policies.name: Amberflo Metering / Billing
policies.exampleHtml:
Amberflo is a usage metering and billing service. This policy allows you to send metering calls for each API to their meter ingest endpoint.

Options

policies.name: API Key Authentication
policies.exampleHtml:
Authenticates requests based on API Keys using Zuplo API Management. You can learn more about the Zuplo API Key Service [here](https://zuplo.com/docs/articles/api-key-api\#buckets)

Options

policies.name: Custom Code Outbound
policies.exampleHtml: A custom outbound response policy.

policies.name: Basic Auth
policies.exampleHtml:
Authenticate requests using basic auth (i.e. username and password)

Options

policies.name: Bot Detection
policies.exampleHtml:
Detect known and suspected bots based on sophisticated traffic analysis.

Options

policies.name: Audit Logs
policies.exampleHtml:
Capture detailed logs of requests for auditing purposes.

Options

policies.name: Auth0 JWT Auth
policies.exampleHtml:
Authenticate users using Auth0 issued JWT tokens.

Options

policies.name: mTLS Auth
policies.exampleHtml: Authenticate requests based on the mTLS protocol.

policies.name: API Key Authentication
policies.exampleHtml:
Authenticates requests based on API Keys using Zuplo API Management. You can learn more about the Zuplo API Key Service [here](https://zuplo.com/docs/articles/api-key-api\#buckets)

Options

policies.name: Caching
policies.exampleHtml:
Respond to matched incoming requests with cached content

Options

policies.name: Change Method
policies.exampleHtml:
Changes the HTTP method of the incoming request.

Options

policies.name: Clear Request Headers
policies.exampleHtml:
Removes all headers from the incoming request except for those in the exclude list.

Options

policies.name: Clear Response Headers
policies.exampleHtml:
Removes all headers from the response except for those in the exclude list.

Options

policies.name: AWS Cognito JWT Auth
policies.exampleHtml:
Authenticate requests with JWT tokens issued by AWS Cognito.

Options

policies.name: Clerk JWT Auth
policies.exampleHtml:
Authenticate users using Clerk issued JWT tokens.

Options

policies.name: Composite Inbound (Group Policies)
policies.exampleHtml:
Creates a composite, or group policy - composed of other policies. For reuse across routes.

Options

policies.name: Firebase JWT Auth
policies.exampleHtml:
Authenticate users using Firebase issued JWT tokens.

Options

policies.name: Moesif Analytics & Billing
policies.exampleHtml:
Moesif is an API analytics and billing service. This policy allows you to send metering calls for each API to their events batch endpoint.

Options

policies.name: Form Data to JSON
policies.exampleHtml:
Converts form data in the incoming request to JSON.

Options

policies.name: LDAP Auth
policies.exampleHtml:
Authenticate requests using an LDAP server.

Options

policies.name: Okta JWT Auth
policies.exampleHtml:
Authenticate users using Okta issued JWT tokens.

Options

policies.name: Mock API Response
policies.exampleHtml:
Returns example responses from the OpenAPI document associated with this route.

Options

policies.name: JWT Auth
policies.exampleHtml:
The Open ID JWT Authentication policy allows you to authenticate incoming requests using an Open ID compliant bearer token.

Options

policies.name: Readme Metrics
policies.exampleHtml:
Readme is a developer documentation and API metrics company. This policy pushes logs to their API calls dashboard.

Options

policies.name: PropelAuth JWT Auth
policies.exampleHtml:
Authenticate users using PropelAuth issued JWT tokens.

Options

policies.name: Remove Response Headers
policies.exampleHtml:
Remove configured headers from the outgoing response.

Options

policies.name: Remove Request Headers
policies.exampleHtml:
Remove headers from the incoming request.

Options

policies.name: Remove Query Parameters
policies.exampleHtml:
Remove query parameters from the incoming request

Options

policies.name: Request Size Limit
policies.exampleHtml:
Enforces a maximum size in bytes of the incoming request.

Options

policies.name: Request Validation
policies.exampleHtml:
Validate inbound requests based on Open API specification

Options

policies.name: Set Body
policies.exampleHtml:
Sets the body of the request in the inbound pipeline - make sure to convert a GET/HEAD request to another method when using this policy.

Options

policies.name: Require Origin

options.failureDetail: Your origin is not authorized to make this request.

policies.exampleHtml:
Sets an allow-list for an origin header

Options

policies.name: Replace String in Response Body
policies.exampleHtml:
Replace a string in the incoming request body

Options

policies.name: Add or Set Query Parameters
policies.exampleHtml:
Adds or sets query parameters on the incoming request.

Options

policies.name: Add or Set Request Headers
policies.exampleHtml:
Adds or sets headers on the incoming request.

Options

policies.name: Set Status Code
policies.exampleHtml:
Adds or sets headers on the on the outgoing.

Options

policies.name: Sleep / Delay
policies.exampleHtml:
Add a delay to the incoming request. Useful for testing.

Options

policies.name: Set Status Code
policies.exampleHtml:
Sets the status code on the on the outgoing response.

Options

policies.name: Supabase JWT Auth
policies.exampleHtml:
The Supabase JWT Authentication policy supports user JWT tokens created by Supabase.

Options

policies.name: Upstream Azure AD Service Auth
policies.exampleHtml:
Uses Azure Active Directory to add an Authorization header to the request in order to authenticate requests using Azure identity.

Options

policies.name: Upstream Firebase Admin Auth
policies.exampleHtml:
Creates a Firebase Admin token and attaches it to the outgoing request. Useful when calling Firebase services as an administrator.

Options

policies.name: Upstream Firebase User Auth
policies.exampleHtml:
Creates a Firebase custom user token and attaches it to the outgoing request. Useful when calling Firebase services as user.

Options

policies.name: Upstream GCP Self-Signed JWT
policies.exampleHtml:
Creates a self-signed JWT token (generated using a Google Service Account JSON) and attaches it to the outgoing request. Useful when calling GCP services like Cloud Endpoints / ESPv2

Options

policies.name: Upstream GCP Service Auth
policies.exampleHtml:
Creates an ID Token from Google's OAuth service and attaches it to the outgoing request. Useful when calling GCP services that are secured with GCP IAM.

Options

policies.name: JSON Body Validation
policies.exampleHtml:
Validates the body of an incoming request based on a JSON schema.

Options

policies.name: Geo-location filtering
policies.exampleHtml:
Block requests based on geo-location parameters: country, region code, and ASN

Options

policies.name: GraphQL Complexity Limit
policies.exampleHtml:
Limits the complexity of a GraphQL query

Options

policies.name: Brown Out
policies.exampleHtml:
Authenticate requests based on the mTLS protocol.

Options

policies.name: Rate Limiting
policies.exampleHtml:
The rate-limiting policy is used to limit the number of requests that can be made against your API based on a key.

Options

policies.name: Custom Code Inbound
policies.exampleHtml:
Enables a custom code policy written in TypeScript. Change YOUR_MODULE to the name of your module (without .ts extension)

Options

policies.name: Transform Request Body
policies.exampleHtml:
This example policy shows how to use request.json() to read the incoming request as a JSON object. The object can then be modified as appropriate. It is then converted back to a string and a new Request is returned in the policy with the new body.

If the incoming request body is not JSON, you can use request.text() or request.blob() to access the contents as raw text or a blob.

policies.name: A/B Test Outbound
policies.exampleHtml:
This example shows how to perform an action on incoming requests based on the result of a randomly generated number. A/B tests could also be performed on properties such as the request.user.

A/B tests can also be combined with other policies by passing data to downstream policies. For example, you could save a value in ContextData based on the results of the A/B test and use that value in a later policy to modify the request.

policies.name: Archive Response to Azure Storage
policies.exampleHtml: In this example shows how you can archive the body of outgoing responses to Azure Blob Storage. This can be useful for auditing, logging, or archival scenarios.

policies.name: Transform Response Body
policies.exampleHtml:
This example policy shows how to use response.json() to read the outgoing response as a JSON object. The object can then be modified as appropriate. It is then converted back to a string and a new Response is returned in the policy with the new body.

If the incoming response body is not JSON, you can use response.text() or response.blob() to access the contents as raw text or a blob.

policies.name: Archive Response to AWS S3
policies.exampleHtml: In this example shows how you can archive the body of outgoing responses to AWS S3 Storage. This can be useful for auditing, logging, or archival scenarios.

policies.name: A/B Test Inbound
policies.exampleHtml:
This example shows how to perform an action on incoming requests based on the result of a randomly generated number. A/B tests could also be performed on properties such as the request.user.

A/B tests can also be combined with other policies by passing data to downstream policies. For example, you could save a value in ContextData based on the results of the A/B test and use that value in a later policy to modify the request.

policies.name: Archive Request to AWS S3
policies.exampleHtml: In this example shows how you can archive the body of incoming requests to AWS S3 Storage. This can be useful for auditing, logging, or archival scenarios. Additionally, you could use this policy to save the body of a request and then enqueue some async work that uses this body.

policies.name: Archive Request to Azure Storage
policies.exampleHtml: In this example shows how you can archive the body of incoming requests to Azure Blob Storage. This can be useful for auditing, logging, or archival scenarios. Additionally, you could use this policy to save the body of a request and then enqueue some async work that uses this body.

policies.name: RBAC Authorization
policies.exampleHtml: RBAC policies can be built many ways depending on your requirements. This example shows how to perform a simple check of whether or not the current user is a member of a set of allowed roles.

policies.name: Access Control List
policies.exampleHtml:
ACL policies can be built many ways depending on your requirements. This example shows how to perform an authorization check on a hard-coded list of users.

This policy could be extended to fetch data from external sources or even use an authorization service such as OpenFGA.

policies.name: IP Restriction
policies.exampleHtml:
This custom policy allows you to specify a set of IP addresses that are allowed or blocked from making requests on your API. This can be useful for adding light-weight security to your API in non-critical scenarios. For example, if you want to ensure only employees on your corporate VPN cannot access development environments.

Generally, this policy should not be relied upon as the only security for protecting sensitive workloads.

policies.name: HMAC Auth
policies.exampleHtml:
This example policy demonstrates how to use a shared secret to create an HMAC signature to sign a payload (in this case the body). When the request is sent, the signature is sent in the request header. The policy can then verify that the signature matches the payload - thus ensuring that the sender had the same shared secret.

This policy is configured with the value of the secret. Normally, you would store this as an environment variable secret. Additionally, the policy option headerName is used to set the header that will be used by the client to send the signature.
